entry.title: Title:"Document Identification When Combining Multiple Standard Reports (SD/MM/FI)
entry.content:
Hi SAP Community,

I have a question regarding document identification when combining multiple standard reports in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition.

Background:
Due to limitations on creating custom reports in Public Edition, we are considering outputting multiple standard reports and linking them by key fields to create a combined document.

Questions:

1. Document numbers can overlap across SD/MM/FI modules. How should we identify documents uniquely?

Example:
- SD Sales Document Number: 1234567890
- MM Purchasing Document Number: 1234567890
- FI Accounting Document Number: 1234567890

2. What combination of fields is required to uniquely identify a document?
- Is Document Number + Document Type sufficient?
- Are Company Code, Fiscal Year, and Organization (Sales Org/Purchasing Org) also required?

3. When linking reports from different modules (e.g., SD report and FI report), what common key fields should be used?
Do we need to use reference document number fields?

4. Are there limitations on which key fields can be output in standard reports?
Are there cases where necessary identification fields cannot be output in certain reports?

I would appreciate any insights from actual implementation experience or best practices.

Thank you in advance!

entry.title: Reducing Bias Through Data Masking in SAP AI Core Orchestration Service.
entry.content:
Understanding Bias in AI Systems

According to SAP Global AI Ethics Policy, bias is “An inclination or prejudice for or against one person or group, especially in a way considered to be unfair.”

As the SAP AI Ethics Handbook notes, ”Bias in AI systems can harm individuals and SAP’s customers by perpetuating societal patterns of marginalization, inequality, and discriminations”.

SAP has chosen to ground the new version of the SAP Global AI Ethics Policy in the “Recommendation on the Ethics of Artificial Intelligence” by UNESCO and the company has adopted a comprehensive strategy to support the principle of “Fairness and Non-Discrimination” - promoting and protecting fairness by respecting all forms of diversity and making all reasonable efforts to avoid discriminatory or biased outcomes in its AI systems.

Why LLMs Are Biased

Large Language Models (LLMs) learn from enormous volumes of text written by people — news articles, books, websites, and social media posts. Because this data reflects human society, it also contains human biases. Consequently, models can unintentionally generate outputs that mirror or even amplify stereotypes and inequalities.

For example:

  • When asked to suggest candidates for a leadership position, a model may favor male names, reflecting historic gender imbalances in leadership roles.
  • When describing occupations, it may pair “nurse” with “she” or “engineer” with “he.”
  • When writing about regions or nationalities, it might use more positive adjectives for Western countries and stereotypical ones for others.
  • When generating sample customer names, it might overrepresent certain ethnicities, underrepresenting others.

Because these biases can appear subtly — in tone, phrasing, or decision logic — it’s critical for organizations to proactively detect and mitigate them to ensure fairness, accuracy, and trust in AI systems.

A Key Strategy for Reducing Bias and Enhancing Fairness in AI: Data Masking

SAP AI Core on SAP Business Technology Platform (SAP BTP) provides an orchestration service for generative AI. This service provides features to help SAP developers, partners, and customers build secure, compliant, and context-aware AI solutions with improved data privacy, multilingual support, and enhanced content control, thus accelerating enterprise-ready AI deployment and usage in SAP environments. In this blog we will discuss, with an HR example related to the hiring process, how the data masking feature, of the orchestration service, can be used to proactively safeguard against bias, enhancing fairness and ethical integrity of AI models in real-world scenarios.

 

The example will show the user interface and functionality of the SAP AI Core orchestration service. We will use a LLM commercially available in the market but we intentionally omit its name to avoid introducing bias or assumptions related to model selection. The objective of this blog is to illustrate how data masking techniques can help mitigate some of the biases that manifest in AI systems —regardless of the underlying model.

Fair Hiring: Using Data Masking to Eliminate Bias

In the below hiring scenario we will task an AI model to act as an experienced recruiter reviewing resumes for a “High-Risk Deep Mining Job” that requires significant physical strength. The system prompt reads:

“You are an Experienced recruiter and from the provided resume you need to select or reject candidates for a Very High Risk Deep Mining Job requiring a lot of physical strength. After taking a look at the resume please provide SELECTED or REJECTED and reason as response”

 

Now we would provide the model with a female applicant’s resume to process and decide on whether to select or reject, and to provide a reason for its decision to see if there is any bias. Please find the sample resume as below,

“Name: Sarah Thompson 

Email: sarah.thompson@example.com 

Phone: (555) 789-1234 

Address: 567 Pine Valley Rd, Colorado 

Gender: female

Objective: 

Seeking a mining role. 

Experience: 

- Deep Mining Specialist, Rocky Core Mines (2022–Present) 

  - Operated heavy machinery and drilling equipment.

  - Managed mine safety protocols and emergency response drills. 

Skills: 

- Strong adherence to safety regulations 

Certifications:  

- Advanced Mining Safety Training  ”

The model processes the resume and rejects the candidate with the reason as below,

“While Sarah has relevant experience as a Deep Mining Specialist and strong adherence to safety regulations, the resume does not provide sufficient evidence of physical strength or endurance, which are critical for a Very High Risk Deep Mining job. Additionally, there are no specific achievements or physical capabilities highlighted that demonstrate she is suited for the demanding physical nature of the role.”

The model’s output demonstrates gender bias—specifically, bias based on stereotypical assumptions about physical capability and endurance in relation to gender. The reasoning is problematic because it applies an unsubstantiated standard, "physical strength or endurance", that disproportionately impacts female candidates without any objective validation.

To further illustrate the pattern, we can test the same model with a similar resume — this time for a male applicant with identical qualifications, and only the personal information changed as below,

“Name: Richard Thompson 

Email: richard.thompson@example.com 

Phone: (555) 789-1234 

Address: 567 Pine Valley Rd, Colorado 

Gender: male …”

 

 

The applicant is selected, and the AI model even infers that the candidate has the necessary physical strength. This highlights how gender bias can influence AI-generated decisions.

To mitigate this and to make the selection process fair, let us now use the data masking functionality provided by the SAP AI Core’s orchestration service and hide identifiers such as:

  • Email Addresses
  • Gender
  • Gender Pronouns
  • Person Names

We now rerun the same evaluation in the hope to see if the process can avoid disparate treatment of reinforcing stereotypes that women are inherently less suited for physically demanding roles, even when their professional credentials match the job requirements. 

And eureka! the applicant is now selected with the below reasoning,

“The candidate has relevant experience as a Deep Mining Specialist and has operated heavy machinery, indicating they possess the necessary skills for a physically demanding role. Additionally, their strong adherence to safety regulations and certification in advanced mining safety training further supports their qualification for a very high-risk deep mining job”

 

Conclusion

This exercise shows how LLMs can reflect existing societal biases — and how techniques like data masking can help mitigate some of them. By hiding personal identifiers before model inference, organizations can promote more equitable outcomes and uphold ethical AI principles in practice.

Helpful Links

  • SAP AI Core
  • Orchestration Workflow V2 | SAP Help Portal
  • Data Masking | SAP Help Portal
  • SAP Global AI Ethics Policy
  • SAP AI Ethics Handbook
  • Recommendation on the Ethics of Artificial Intelligence

entry.title: Join the Beta: AI-Assisted Incoming Bills of Exchange Posting
entry.content:
Are you ready to transform your Bill of Exchange processes in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition?

We’re excited to invite you to participate in the beta testing program for an innovative new capability: AI-Assisted Incoming Bills of Exchange Posting.


This feature, set to be available for early access with the February 14, 2026 release(2602), leverages AI to simplify and streamline the handling of incoming Bills of Exchange (BoE). The current focus is on key regions such as Japan, China, France, Turkey, and the United Arab Emirates.

Managing Bills of Exchange can be a time-consuming task that involves extracting and interpreting large amounts of data. This new AI-powered capability aims to make your life easier by automating the extraction, mapping, and posting of BoE information directly within the application. The result: faster processing, reduced errors, and enhanced efficiency.

As a beta participant, you’ll have the opportunity to test this feature in your own SAP S/4HANA Cloud system. Your feedback will be invaluable in shaping the future of this tool. We will also organize regular meetings to share updates and collect your insights, ensuring that the tool evolves in a way that truly benefits your business processes.

Key Dates

  • Registration: October 21, 2025 - January 15, 2026
  • Program Start: February 14, 2026
  • Duration: 90 days

Seats are limited, so act fast! To participate, you must be an SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition customer or partner and sign a Test Evaluation Agreement.

Ready to get involved? Visit the BETA Campaign and click the Register button at the top left to secure your spot. Together, let's make handling Bills of Exchange more efficient and straightforward!

entry.title: How to Track Offsetting Accounts Through Interim Accounts (e.g., Payables → GR/IR → Inventory) in S/
entry.content:
Hi SAP Community,

I have a question about tracking offsetting accounts through interim accounts in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition.

Scenario:
In the procurement process with GR/IR clearing account, the accounting flow is:

1. Goods Receipt:
DR: Inventory 100
CR: GR/IR Clearing Account 100

2. Invoice Receipt:
DR: GR/IR Clearing Account 100
CR: Accounts Payable 100

Question:
When reviewing Accounts Payable line items, the offsetting account shows "GR/IR Clearing Account." However, we need to trace back to the original offsetting account (Inventory) that was posted when the goods were received.

In other words: Accounts Payable → GR/IR → **Inventory**

Is there a standard way in Public Edition to:
1. Display this multi-level offsetting account relationship in a single report?
2. Download a list showing the complete flow (AP → GR/IR → Inventory)?
3. Automatically link the invoice document to the original goods receipt accounting document?

Current Understanding:
- FI documents only show direct offsetting accounts (1-to-1 relationship)
- Standard reports like "Display Journal Entries" show GR/IR details but don't automatically link to the original inventory posting

Questions:
1. Is there a standard Fiori app or report that can trace through interim accounts?
2. Does the "Manage GR/IR Clearing Account" app (if available) provide this functionality?
3. Would we need to use custom queries via BTP/SAC to achieve this?
4. Are there any best practices for this requirement in Public Edition?

Any insights from actual implementation experience would be greatly appreciated!

Thank you in advance!

entry.title: Re: What is the best practice recommendation for Cost Cen...
entry.content:
Hi Aparna,

As far as I know, in SAP SuccessFactors Employee Central, the recommended best practice is to associate Cost Centers with the Legal Entity, not directly with lower-level org units such as Departments or Divisions.

The reason is that Cost Centers are finance-driven objects used for accounting and reporting purposes. Legal Entities represent the financial and statutory boundary of an organization, making them the correct parent object for cost centers. This setup ensures consistency, supports seamless integration with SAP ERP/S/4HANA, and simplifies financial reporting and cost allocation.

If the business requires cost centers to be defined at a more granular level (e.g., department-specific budgets), you can still maintain the Legal Entity as the primary association and use business rules to default a specific cost center based on department or division.

In summary,

Recommendation: Cost Center associated to Legal entity

Optional: Cost Ceneter associated to Department/Division (only if business requires)

 

Thank you.

entry.title: Can We Download App ID, Reference Information, and Object Text with Journal Entries/G/L Account Line
entry.content:
Hi SAP Community,

We have a question about downloadable fields when exporting journal entries and G/L account line items in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition.

Background:
We operate with multiple company codes and plants, and need to track:
- Which app was used to post each document
- Whether posting was manual or automatic
- Reference/source information

Questions:

When downloading data from standard apps like:
- Display Journal Entries
- Display G/L Account Line Items

Can we include the following fields in the download?

1. **App ID (Transaction Code equivalent)**
- Which Fiori app was used to create the document
- Example: F0717 (Post General Journal Entries), F1814 (Enter Supplier Invoice)
- Or at minimum: Document Type (SA, KR, DR, etc.)

2. **Reference Processing Information**
- Reference Document Number
- Original Document Number
- Purchase Order Number (for MM documents)
- Sales Order Number (for SD documents)
- Any indicator of manual vs. automatic posting

3. **Object Text**
- Document Header Text
- Line Item Text
- Cost Center Text / WBS Text
- (Clarification: We're also not 100% sure what "Object Text" refers to - any insights?)

Current Understanding:
- App ID is likely NOT stored in FI documents
- Reference document numbers might be available
- Various text fields should be available as selection options

Questions:
1. Which of these fields are actually available in standard journal/G/L reports?
2. Can they be added as columns in the download/export?
3. Are there alternative apps or reports that provide this information?
4. Any workarounds if these fields are not available in standard reports?

We're trying to avoid custom development if possible and want to use standard functionality.

Any insights from actual implementation experience would be greatly appreciated!

Thank you in advance!

entry.title: Fichier des Écritures Comptables (FEC)
entry.content:
In France we have a legal requirement to submit a file of accounting entries for the closed fiscal year in a dematerialized format (Article L47 A I ) which is effective from 01.01.2014.

Upon receiving request from the tax authorities, a company has 15 days to prepare and submit the FEC file. In case of failing to deliver the FEC file or in the event of non-compliance, companies could face significant penalties

This file consists of entries after inventory operations, excluding centralization entries and excluding entries for balancing expense and revenue accounts. It includes the entries for the recovery of balances from the previous fiscal year and contains, for each entry, all accounting data present in the company's computerized accounting system, with the first eighteen pieces of information required to correspond, in order, to those listed in the following table:

 

 

Further information about the legal requirements can be found here

Article L47 A - Book of Tax Procedures – Légifrance

Article A47 A-1 - Livre des procédures fiscales - Légifrance

How to generate the FEC file from SAP? 

DRC or DART

Document and Reporting Compliance (DRC)

It enables you to create, process, and monitor electronic documents and statutory reports. As a result, your company stays compliant with local legal obligations.

Statutory reporting has been localized for use by businesses with operations in the country/region and it comprises functions designed for laws and business practices relevant in the country/region.

You can generate the audit file for France using the Run Statutory Reports app. This file is referred to as "FEC - Fichier des Écritures Comptables".

Further information can be found here

Supported Compliance Tasks by Country/Region | SAP Help Portal

Audit File (FEC) | SAP Help Portal

Data Retention Tool (DART)

The Data Retention Tool (DART) helps SAP users to meet the legal requirements concerning data retention and data transfer for tax auditing. You can use DART to extract and store data that is relevant to tax from SAP applications at regular intervals. DART extracts the data into sequential files and provides tools that you can use to display and evaluate the stored data.

In general, two steps are required in DART to create machine-readable files for the tax auditor.

The first step in DART involves generating extract files that capture data based on the selected company code and areas like FI, CO, SD, and MM, with customizable restrictions.

In the second step, extract files are transformed into view files according to tax auditor specifications by defining which segments are included and how they are combined.

Further information can be found here

Introduction to the Data Retention Tool (DART) | SAP Help Portal

What are the technical prerequisites for FEC solution by DART?

The recommendation from SAP is to be on the highest version of DART with all the latest notes implemented.

you can check the DART version in the SE11.

You should choose there the "TYPE GROUP": DART1. Then click display

 

The most important technical prerequisites are included in this note

2162977 - DART: Order of implementation of notes for FEC - SAP for Me

Depending on release & support package of the relevant system, some of them should have been delivered by default.

Configuration for DART can be checked in SAP Help Portal

Configuration | SAP Help Portal

DART is often pre-configured for FEC by the installed SAP notes. You mainly need to Configure the Extract File Directories and set directory paths

What is the exact business process?

The prerequisite before running these processes is that your fiscal year is completely closed!

1st step Posting of opening balances France

2nd step Create DART extracts

3rd step Generation of the FEC

Posting of opening balances France

Run Program RFOPENPOSTING_FR with Tcode SE38 or Tcode FAGL_FR_03

This report creates opening entries for balance sheet accounts from the previous year in accordance with the French requirement to submit posting data to the French tax authorities.

Based on the account balances and open items on the key date, FI documents are posted and form the basis of the data extract. These postings represent the balance carryforward but do not generate balances.

For these postings, no subledger documents (customer/vendor/Asset Accounting) are written.

No open items are generated.

The report is available for classic General Ledger Accounting and new General Ledger Accounting.

The documents are specially indicated:

1) The document status is 'O' (balance sheet opening entry).

2) The reference transaction is 'GLYEC' (year-end closing document).

3) The documents are posted in period '0' of the carryforward year.

Documents are generated for each account, customer, and vendor. Information about the customer and vendor is stored in the LIFNR/KUNNR fields as well as in the assignment.

The balances of the respective balance sheet accounts are cleared against "Balance Sheet Account - Opening" on the selection screen.

The posted documents can be reversed with the FI reversal transactions (FB08/F.80).

Compare entries with G/L account Balance Tcode FAGLB03

New list RFOPENPOSTING_FR 

Account balance

Posting List

New open posting in the FEC file

Process Data in DART

Settings for data extraction with Tcode FTWP

Go to FTW1A create the DART extract select FR for the language

You can analyze the extract using the transaction FTWF

Generate FEC File

Start the view 2FR_FI01 with transaction FTWH

 

Go in transaction FTWN you can display and export your generated data

How to test FEC file

The validation program is available on the ministry website

Outil de test des fichiers des écritures comptables (FEC) | Ministère de l’Économie des Finances et de la Souveraineté industrielle et numérique

After installation, run the program. The screen is the same as the one used by the authorities. You should fill the field "Entrer le numéro alpage du dossier" with your number as the file naming example ("111222333"). This is mandatory.

The second field is optional; you can write the name of your company into this.

Also choose the type of your chart of account on the left column (Type de plan comptable) and the type of the revenue category on the right column (Type de revenus). Then you can upload the file to be tested by clicking on the icon "Selectionner un fichier á traiter".

Select the relevant local file. After that your can start the test by clicking on the "Valider" button.

At the end of the test, a summary document is generated in PDF format. It is automatically displayed and saved. The first page of the summary contains general information about this validation process.

The second page shows the mandatory fields required by the law and the fields of the actual FEC file next to it.

Additional notes and comments about the file are displayed on the third page. Generally, these notes have two types: in some cases, these are problems what should be solved in order to get correct file from technical aspect. For example, if there are missing data, it is displayed under the heading „Données absentes”. There are also informational comments, in these cases the file is technically correct. These are displayed under the heading „Observations complémentaires”.

entry.title: Geofencing capability in SAP SuccessFactors Time Tracking
entry.content:
Overview

Geofencing allows you to ensure that the employees can clock in and clock out only when they are physically present in their designated office premises. Also, this solution helps you to reduce costs associated with terminal devices. Geofencing restricts clock-in/out functionality to a defined geographic area, ensuring time punches are only possible in the desired location. This feature will be available in the SAP SuccessFactors mobile app from the 2H 2025 release.

 Geofences are a set of boundaries defined using a circular or polygonal shape. Any number of shapes in different locations can be grouped under a single geofence.

As administrators, there are many configurations that you can do. Following are some details:

Manage Geofences

  1. Provide permissions to enable geofencing for SAP SuccessFactors Clock In Clock Out. It is important to provide the View and the Assign Geofence Access by Feature Area > Clock In Clock Out permissions. These permissions are respected when the configuration is set up in Clock In Clock Out.
  2. To manage the geofences, go to Admin Center -> Tools -> Company Settings -> Manage Geofences or search for Manage Geofences using Action Search from the Home page.
  3. The Create permission provides the Create and Copy options. The Search option on the map helps to search the location where the boundaries are to be added. The circle and polygon shapes are supported.       
  4. A geofence must be active for it to be assigned to employees. Hence, the activate and deactivate options are provided.        
  5. The Deactivate option is required to modify/delete an existing geofence. The Edit and Delete options appear only when you have the Edit permission.

Assigning Geofences to Clock In Clock Out Employees

In the past, many of you might have already configured Clock In Clock Out. You will now see new additions to the Configure Clock In Clock Out -> Clock In Clock Out Group page.

The Details like Group Details, Location Capture remain the same but there is a new section called Geofences.

When the Enable Geofences is toggled to ON, you can configure geofence assignments.

  • The time event types can be assigned to multiple geofences. For example, Clock In can be assigned to Production Unit 1, Production Unit 2, and so on.
  • The time event type can be assigned to different geofences. For example, Clock In can be assigned to Geofence 1, Geofence 2, and Geofence 3 whereas Clock Out can be assigned to Geofence 4, and Geofence 5.
  • It is not mandatory for the time event type to be always geofenced. For example, the time event type Break is not assigned to any geofence and can be punched inside or outside the geofence.
  • A copy and paste feature help in copying the geofences from one time event type to another if they were the same to avoid manual selection and thus save time.

The location capture and geofences functionalities are independent of each other. Geofence only provides the boundary of the desired location where a punch was made. If you would like to know the exact geographical co-ordinates, then it is important to enable Location Capture.

Once the assignments for the geofence is done, ensure that the Clock In Clock Out group is assigned in the Time Information of the employee.

Employee Experience:

Employee can see the map with the geofence boundaries if the geofence is enabled and atleast one geofence is configured in the Clock In Clock Out Group assigned in Time Information for that employee.

  • It is important to enable location services and the precise location on mobile. If this is not enabled, the geofenced time event type will not be shown when Clock Time quick action is opened on the SAP SuccessFactors mobile application.
  • A geofence boundary on the map is shown so that the employee if already within the boundary, can punch the geofenced time event types.
  • The non-geofenced time event types are shown all the time irrespective of the geofence boundary.
  • If the employee is not within the geofence boundary, an information is displayed just below the map to indicate that the employee is at a certain distance away from the nearest geofence boundary. For example, a radial distance of 10 meters. The geofenced time event types will not be availableand cannot be punched.
  • If location capture is enabled for an employee, then the co-ordinates are captured during the punch.

                                   

Screenshot 1 - Employee is outside the geofence. Screenshot 2 - Employee is within the geofence

The above example is where the employee has time event types that are geofenced.

Limitations:

  • Google Maps is used to render the maps for Geofencing functionality. If Google Maps isn't supported in your country/region, then you won't be able to use the Geofencing feature.
  • Currently, there is a limit of 200 geofences which can be shown during assignment to a time event type in the Configure Clock In Clock Out page. This limitation is only for 2H 2025.
  • Location service and Precise location are mandatory options to use the geofencing feature on mobile. If location service is enabled but precise location is not enabled, then geofenced time event types will never be enabled to punch.

Future Enhancements:

  • Reporting of Time Events with geofence information as shown in the Manage Clock In Clock Out page with geofence name and code to know where the employee punched.
  • Manual Time Events will have the geofence field for the use case when an employee is within the geofence but forgets to punch and must record a manual time event later.
  • Transporting geofences from one environment to another using Configuration Transport Center.
  • Import and Export of Geofences to help customers to get data already recorded from existing systems to SAP SuccessFactors Time Tracking.

Conclusion:

Geofence configuration is made simpler and easier. Defining shapes via map will help provide exact co-ordinates. Geofenced time event types are visible only on mobile to punch. This helps in restricting employees to punch when they are not in the desired location. There is no additional configuration in other areas like job information or location information. 

We plan to enhance this feature to make it easy for customers and partners during configuration, maintenance and usability. Let us know your feedback in the comments and the enhancements you would like to see for this feature.

entry.title: Add Personnel Number Field to EmployeeTime Object and UI in SAP SuccessFactors
entry.content:
Hello experts,

We have an integration set up between SAP HCM and SAP SuccessFactors Employee Central.
The employee master data, including the Personnal Number (PERNR) like a 00005010, is successfully transferred from SAP HCM to Employee Central.

When an employee submits an absence request in the Employee Time (EmployeeTime) section, the form displays the employee’s name, time type, work schedule, and other fields but the Personnel Number is not shown.

We have created a custom field in the EmployeeTime object called cust_userIdDisplay, and we have already added this field to the UI (EmployeeTime form).

 

We would like to get guidelines or best practices on how to properly configure the field details for example, how to derive or display the employee’s Personnel Number (PERNR) from the related user or employee record in Employee Central.

We need the Personnel Number to be displayed in the absence request form for reference purposes.

Could you please advise:

  • how to add the Personnel Number field to the EmployeeTime object; and

  • how to configure the user interface (UI) so that this field is visible when submitting or viewing an absence request?

Any step-by-step guidance or related documentation links would be greatly appreciated.

Thank you!

entry.title: Evolution of Data and Analytics with SAP Business Data Cloud
entry.content:
Introduction to Business Data Cloud:

SAP Business Data Cloud was introduced on February 13 2025 as Software-as-a-Service (SaaS) solution fully managed by SAP. SAP Business Data Cloud is a data & analytics platform that harmonizes all data from SAP and non-SAP sources into a unified semantic layer of trusted data that governs, connects and share data securely across systems or cloud. By integrating powerful functionality of SAP Datasphere, SAP Analytics Cloud, and SAP Databricks and SAP Business Warehouse. It empowers businesses to break data silos to power advanced AI and analytics.

Why was Business data cloud introduced?

  • To get easier access to SAP data without the need for complex data preparation steps such as extraction, building semantics, transformation and loading data for analytics.
  • To get access to all SAP data from all Line of Business (LoB) applications, such as SAP S/4HANA, SAP SuccessFactors and SAP Ariba without the need of 3rd party connector & tool.
  • To get a unified business view of the data regardless of which SAP application it originated from without making harmonization difficult and holds its original business context without any change.
  • To accelerate AI with trusted and secure data that they can use to build reliable AI applications to accelerate innovation and insights with AI.
  • To get faster access to SAP data insights by removing data preparation and dashboard building steps.
  • To get a Simplified Landscape by reducing multiple tools, silos and complex tasks of manual data preparation, development and analytics.

Key Features & Capabilities of Business Data Cloud: 

SAP Business Data Cloud Key Innovation of out-of-the-box components

  • Intelligent Applications: Intelligent Applications are predefined, SAP-managed dashboards for analytics based on underlying Data Products and models.
  • Data Products: Create and share governed, reusable data products that deliver consistent, high-quality business information across teams and systems.
  • BDC Cockpit: Centrally manage your data products, monitor usage, and enforce governance policies, all from one intuitive interface.

SAP Business Data Cloud Integrated Software components:

  • SAP Datasphere: to provide the data integration and modelling.
  • SAP Analytics Cloud: to provide the analysis and planning.
  • SAP Databricks: to provide AI and machine learning enhancements.
  • SAP BW/BW4HANA: can be used as a data source for datasphere & databricks.

SAP Business Data Cloud is built on SAP Business Technology Platform:

  • Unified Customer Landscape used to connect the SAP Business Data Cloud components.
  • SAP HANA Cloud provides the data storage layer.
  • SAP Security and Compliance to manage access and permissions and governs regulatory compliance.
  • SAP Development & Integration to provide developer tools for modelling & data Integration
  • SAP AI & Analytics to provide advanced analytics and AI powered insights.

SAP Business Data Cloud Architecture:

  • Source System layer: It harmonizes all data from SAP and non-SAP sources, into a unified semantic layer of trusted data, to power advanced analytics and to build AI applications.
  • Foundation Service Layer: This layer replicates and harmonizes data from the source systems to produce curated, governed Data Products that retain their original business context. Data products are grouped by Data Packages to make it easy to discover them and to activate them. This data is stored in a hyper scaler environment using SAP HANA Cloud and Data Lake files.
  • Business Data Fabric Layer: It combines the strengths of SAP Datasphere, SAP Analytics Cloud (SAC), and SAP Business Warehouse (BW) capabilities, enhanced by the Databricks platform to unify an organization with SAP and Non – SAP and third-party data into a single, trusted foundation model.
  • SAP Datasphere is the technological foundation for the business data fabric within BDC. It integrates, transforms, and enriches data from SAP and non-SAP sources into powerful semantic models. Data can be replicated into Datasphere for faster performance or accessed virtually from its source, allowing for flexible management of a hybrid data landscape.
  • SAP Databricks is an Advanced AI and machine learning technology. It provides a pro-code environment for data engineers and AI developers to build, train, and deploy custom AI and ML models using the rich, semantically aware data from SAP applications.
  • SAP Business Warehouse (BW) or BW/4HANA: For customers with existing on-premises SAP Business Warehouse (BW) or BW/4HANA systems, this component provides a modernization path within the Business Data Fabric. A Data Product Generator can be used to convert BW Info Provider data into cloud-ready data products, which can then be consumed by Datasphere for analytics or by Databricks for AI/ML.
  • SAP Business Data Cockpit: SAP Business Data Cloud cockpit allows you to browse and find pre delivered Intelligent Applications and data products, install Intelligent Applications, and share data products with SAP Datasphere & Databricks to enable analytics & enrich with AI and machine learning capabilities.
  • Intelligent Application Layer: It’s a unified semantic layer of trusted data, to power advanced AI & Analytics.
  • SAP Analytical Cloud: Using SAP Analytics Cloud, business users can run ad-hoc analysis, explore the provided data with AI-driven chat capabilities, or act on their insights with AI-driven suggestions, bridging the gap between analytics and their end-to-end business processes.
  • Intelligent Application: SAP Business Data Cloud Intelligent Applications are used to provide the required dashboard in out-of-the-box reporting scenarios with its advanced visualization and planning functions
  • Joule: Joule uses natural language processing to interact, access insights, and perform tasks across SAP and third-party applications. It uses "agents" and "skills" to automate multi-step workflows and provide contextual assistance.

How SAP Business Data Cloud work as one domain model:

Scenario 1: Out-of-the-Box model with Datasphere

Step 1: The first step is to identify the right intelligent application for your business scenario, In SAP Business Data Cloud cockpit search for available intelligent application and install the one that meets your requirement.

Step 2: When intelligent application installation is initiated the relevant business data that has already been bundled into a package in your business application is accessed and replicated to the Foundation Services of SAP Business Data Cloud.

Step 3: Inside the Foundation Services, the replicated business data is harmonized with other data packages from different business applications such as SAP SuccessFactors the data is transformed and enriched to become a data product. The data is now ready to be used as the basis for analysis.

Step 4: In SAP Datasphere all artifacts necessary for the analysis are now automatically generated on top of the Data Product. 

Step 5: Visual representations of the insights are automatically generated and made available in the intelligent application dashboard.

 Scenario 2:  AI and machine learning enhancement by Databricks

Step 1: The first step is to identify the right intelligent application for your business scenario, In SAP Business Data Cloud cockpit search for available intelligent application and install the one that meets your requirement.

Step 2: When intelligent application installation is initiated the relevant business data that has already been bundled into a package in your business application is accessed and replicated to the Foundation Services of SAP Business Data Cloud.

Step 3: Inside the Foundation Services, the replicated business data is harmonized with other data packages from different business applications such as SAP SuccessFactors the data is transformed and enriched to become a data product. The data is now ready to be used as the basis for analysis.

Step 4: In SAP Datasphere all artifacts necessary for the analysis are now automatically generated on top of the Data Product. 

Step 5: Visual representations of the insights are automatically generated and made available in the intelligent application dashboard.

Step 6: Integration of SAP Databricks

It is possible to extend the results shown in the dashboard with machine learning and AI based Insights, to do so use the SAP business data cockpit to share data product with databricks,

In SAP Databricks AI and Machine learning techniques are used to generate the desired result, this results then shared back to the data model and extend your dashboard with AI and Machine learning insights.

Scenario 2:  : Integration of SAP BW & SAP Analytical Cloud

Step 1: The first step is to identify the right intelligent application for your business scenario, In SAP BDC cockpit search for available intelligent application and install the one that meets your requirement.

Step 2: When intelligent application installation is initiated the relevant business data that has already been bundled into a package in your business application is accessed and replicated to the Foundation Services of SAP Business Data Cloud.

Step 3: Inside the Foundation Services, the replicated business data is harmonized with other data packages from different business applications such as SAP SuccessFactors the data is transformed and enriched to become a data product. The data is now ready to be used as the basis for analysis.

Step 4: In SAP Datasphere all artifacts necessary for the analysis are now automatically generated on top of the Data Product. 

Step 5: This is where the integration of your third-party data comes into play. The advanced integration and data modelling capabilities of SAP Datasphere allow you to integrate your third-party data into the out-of-the-box data model.

Step 6: Integration of SAP BW

It is also possible to integrate your existing objects from SAP BW/4HANA into SAP Business Data Cloud. With a dedicated data provisioning tool, you can onboard your SAP BW objects into SAP Datasphere and combine them with the existing data model.

Step 7: Integration of SAP Analytical Cloud 

SAP Business Data Cloud provides a wide range of consumption options on top of your data model. Use the AI-based Just Ask feature in SAP Analytics Cloud. The power of its natural language processing allows you to request information from your data model simply by typing a question about your data. Answers are instantly displayed in the most appropriate format.

Role of Source system & Data product in BDC:

Role of Datasphere in BDC:

 Role of Databricks in BDC:

 Role of BW in BDC:

 Role of SAC in BDC:

 Role of Intelligent Application Dashboard & Joule in BDC:

 
Use Case of Business Data Cloud:

SAP Business Data Cloud can handle many use-cases including:

  • Data Integration & Modelling 
  • Data Governance and Compliance 
  • Development of AI and machine learning models
  • Data Warehousing
  • Planning and BI 
  • Development of intelligent applications to support all business processes.
  • End-to-end data lifecycle management by SAP 

SAP Business Data Cloud reaches all personas of the organization.

Conclusion: 

Data from all SAP applications is combined and made available to the businesses under a single domain model. With SAP Business Data Cloud, SAP has reached the next level of data and analytics evolution to tackle challenges and enables businesses to seamlessly integrate, harmonize, and analyse data from multiple sources, transforming raw data into valuable insights with advanced AI and analytics. 

By adopting the latest 2025 features, organizations can accelerate analytics, improve decision-making, and prepare for AI-driven innovation.

Reference:

Learning Journey: https://learning.sap.com/learning-journeys/exploring-sap-business-data-cloud
Live Session : https://learning.sap.com/live-sessions/overview-of-sap-business-data-cloud
SAP Help Document : https://help.sap.com/docs/business-data-cloud
GenAI Assistance : Assistance in drafting the structure of blog.

entry.title: SAP Business AI中的定制化AI能力Joule for Consultant概况介绍
entry.content:
如果您对BTP感兴趣，BTP个人精选内容目录 | SAP Blogs 可能有更多你需要的内容

 

还在为复杂的SAP项目而夜不能寐？每天花费大量时间搜索技术文档和最佳实践？

作为SAP顾问的你，是否经常遇到这样的困扰：客户急需解决方案，你却要在海量文档中反复搜索；面对复杂的ABAP代码，需要花费数小时理解业务逻辑；项目紧急却找不到资深专家指导。

现在，一个革命性的AI助手正在改变这一切——SAP Joule for Consultant，它将成为你身边24/7在线的SAP专家，让你的专业能力瞬间提升，项目交付效率翻倍。

 

SAP Joule for Consultant是什么？

SAP Joule for Consultant是一个网页形式的对话助手，专为SAP顾问设计，通过自然语言对话提供专家级指导和实时答案

它是SAP Business AI产品组合中的独立SaaS产品，定位为专门服务咨询顾问

 

SAP为什么要开发SAP Joule for Consultant？

痛点分析：

SAP顾问在学习和项目中需要频繁搜索信息和最佳实践，影响项目交付效率

开发目的：

通过AI技术缩短项目实施时间，提高决策质量，让顾问能够更快速地获得专家级指导和准确答案

核心价值主张：

让最靠谱的SAP知识触手可及，帮助顾问团队更快、更高质量、更自信地交付SAP项目

 

SAP Joule for Consultant的核心能力有哪些？

SAP问题回答，资料搜索：

提供SAP领域的全面洞察，回答产品名称、实体定义、SAP概念、程序、流程和功能能力相关问题

SAP相关故障排除：

为解决SAP系统和业务流程中的功能问题或操作挑战提供精确解决方案

ABAP代码解释：

通过了解并提取ABAP代码，进而解释其业务逻辑和技术特征（更多ABAP代码相关功能归属在Joule for Developer功能中）

 

例如我们向Joule for Consultant提问：

S/4HANA的'Universal Journal'概念如何改变了传统ERP的数据存储逻辑？它与ECC中的多个分类账表相比有什么本质区别？带来了什么好处？

 

在回答的结尾，可以看到文中不同内容的信息源，其更多引用SAP来源的高质量信息，而非未知来源的信息

 

SAP Joule for Consultant和市面上常见的类似功能有什么区别？

  • 基于专门训练的模型，能够深度理解ABAP和CDS代码逻辑，了解常见SAP和用户业务术语
  • 拥有20万+页SAP内容的记忆储备，相当于100+个SAP认证的内容量，其中大部分内容都是SAP独有的，外部AI助手无法访问，包括SAP Community, Notes, Help技术文档，Tutorial教程等内容

 

SAP Joule for Consultant该怎么用呢？

Joule for Consultant可以轻松嵌入SAP项目的所有阶段，回答所有SAP相关的问题，并通过提供源文档链接以保证答案的可信度

实施过程

由Admin在SAP for me激活Joule for consultant，在BTP中获取授权

在BTP中创建服务，为用户提供权限

用户通过URL进入主页开始使用

 

总结

SAP Joule for Consultant通过结合生成式AI与SAP独有的权威知识库，为顾问提供专家级指导，显著提升项目交付效率和质量。

关于本文内容有任何问题或见解，欢迎在评论区留下你的想法

entry.title: Esri study shows HANA Cloud is a good choice for your ArcGIS Enterprise Geodatabase
entry.content:
I've been blogging about SAP HANA Cloud, SAP HANA database as a great option for your enterprise geodatabase since 2021.  As long as HANA Cloud is in the same region and the same hyperscalar as SAP S/4HANA in RISE with SAP , you will get optimal performance by minimizing network latency.  I am elated that Esri has run this preliminary test and will run a more extensive test scaling user load at a later date.  They have confirmed what I've been blogging about for 4+ years!  If you want to check out all of my blogs on ArcGIS - SAP integration on SAP Community, you can read my blogs, you can view them all here. and here.

The blog in the ArcGIS Architecture Center (see my first blog on SAP Community for more information on Esri's work) describes a test Esri conducted to simulate a medium size gas utility running a standard set of real world workflows consisting of 15 editors and 200 web viewers.  The Utility Network consists of a dataset with a geographic extent of roughly 55,000 square miles, and with an overall size of approximately 45 GB. The dataset contained roughly nine million features, 700 sub-networks, and 300,000 gas meters.  Esri has run these same set of tests against #RISE with SAP and you can find details in that blog on how Esri runs these tests, what the workflows are and what other HANA related tests they've run.

Here are the performance graphs from the test that Esri just ran.  There is plenty of headroom (CPU, memory and disk) and workflows are executing in a timely fashion - workflows aren't building up because the system is running with good performance.  SAP HANA Cloud, SAP HANA database is using < 4% CPU (6th graph from the top on the left).

If you compare these results to the results from the RISE with SAP study that Esri ran in April, you will see there is plenty of headroom both on HANA Cloud and on the ArcGIS servers.  Even though this is a 1x expected load (15 editors and 200 web users), I expect when Esri runs 2x, 4x and higher number of users, HANA Cloud will behave similarly to the graphs below which show 8x the number of users against HANA cloud-resident in RISE with SAP .  This graph also shows Single VPC which means HANA cloud-resident and ArcGIS Enterprise in the same VPC.

ArcGIS on HANA in RISE with SAP

Performance is important, but what else does this mean to utilities who are in RISE with SAP and need to put their ArcGIS Enterprise landscape and geodatabase in the cloud?  It means that HANA Cloud is a viable choice that brings along with it the ability to expose SAP S/4HANA Plant Maintenance master and transactional data in workflows via ArcGIS Enterprise.  Not only does this produce more efficient workflows and business processes but this also means ArcGIS powerful spatial analytics can be applied to that master and transactional data within the context of asset location, DERs and power consumption (due to EV charging for instance).  With these two systems of record for a utility in the SAP Business Technology Platform , this opens the door to GeoAI and leveraging that data with SAP Business Data Cloud.

Even more compelling is that as SAP customers embrace SAP S/4HANA Cloud, extended edition, they can integrate their spatial, master and transactional data the same way because SAP HANA Cloud, SAP HANA database has the ability to connect to SAP S/4HANA Cloud, extended edition.. That means ArcGIS Enterprise can query ABAP CDS views to obtain master and transactional data on the fly - just like ArcGIS on SAP HANA and RISE with SAP S/4HANA.  What makes this possible is both SAP HANA (as of HANA 2 SPS8) and SAP HANA Cloud, SAP HANA database now support the ABAP ODBC driver which can connect to both on-prem and cloud resident S/4HANA instances and well as S/4HANA Cloud.

With SAP and Esri customers successfully leveraging the SAP - ArcGIS integration in both cloud, cloud resident and on-prem landscapes and Esri showing HANA Cloud performs well, now is the time put your geodatabases on SAP HANA Cloud, SAP HANA database and realize the same value that OGE, NiSource and others are.

Note: the screenshots are from the Esri studies linked to in this blog.  All rights belong to their respective owners.

entry.content: Hi Chris, Thanks for your response. Unfortunately, the packaging specifications are not available in Cloud. They are ERP Packaging Instructions (https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_CLOUD/32da8359c8ee4e8b8e8c5e15cacba5aa/758cbf53f106b44ce10000000a174cb4.html?locale=en-US ). Routing everything to a packing workstation would turn a process that currently takes one hour into a two-step process, since they would need to pick the material from the warehouse and move it to another location just to prepare it, instead of completing everything in a single step. I am exploring the BAdIs available for “Pack Outbound Deliveries,” because if the material is already correctly packed, there is no need to pack it again. However, it seems that there are no suitable BAdIs in Advanced, and even then it doesn’t feel like a good solution. I am also checking what options I have via SAP PERSONAS to influence or validate the packaging material field when creating the Pick HU, but I have the impression that this won’t work either. Regards.

entry.title: Innovating for a Circular Future: What’s new in Waste and Recycling in S/4HANA 2025
entry.content:
As the world continues to place increasing emphasis on sustainability – waste management and recycling have taken center stage in the journey towards a circular economy. At SAP, we are committed to support this shift and provide continuous innovation in our Waste and Recycling solution. In this blog, I’m excited to share some of the key innovations and features with the latest release of S/4HANA 2025 FPS0.

1. Laying the foundation with CDS Views

Core Data Services (CDS) Views have emerged as a cornerstone of modern SAP system architecture, enabling streamlined data modelling and real-time access to relevant information. In the context of SAP Waste and Recycling, CDS Views provide the foundation for efficient data management and analytics by centralizing and structuring data across various modules. This not only simplifies reporting and operational decision-making but also paves the way for more advanced capabilities, such as analytics and integrations. Some of the CDS views are also available from the previous release (2023).

  • Waste Disposal Orders

SAP waste disposal orders are core documents used in SAP S/4HANA for Waste and Recycling to manage and track the collection and transport of waste on specific planned routes. The order includes a header (route, date, start time) and line items (customer, contract, service type, address). For further information, refer - Analysis and Overview of Waste Disposal Orders

  • Weighing Documents

When vehicles carrying waste arrive at, or leave, a facility such as a landfill, incineration plant, or recycling center, they are weighed using a connected weighbridge, and these results are recorded directly in SAP S/4HANA as weighing transactions. These transactions are directly linked to waste disposal orders or contracts ensuring that the actual quantities collected, delivered, or processed are precisely documented and associated with the correct customer, contract, and order item. This ensures transparency for billing, regulatory compliance, and operational analysis. For further information, refer - Weighing Transactions – Multi Item Weighing

  • Containers Management

Container allocation forms the central component that binds the technical equipment information (containers) with the relevant service information (waste materials, service types, frequency, start dates etc. For further information, refer Containers Tracking

  • Route Management

CDS views for Routes provide information related to different routes based on region, service types, service areas, container categories etc. You can also enable the retrieval of route identification with equipment, service number item details with its service location, interval type, and category, and resources related to the route. For further details pls refer -  Routes

  • Waste Sales Contracts

This CDS view is for the waste specific sales contracts. It provides a view of the contracts which are active and have containers allocated to their premise. For further details, refer Waste & Recycling Sales Contracts

2. Tare Based Weighing

Tare weight or vehicle weight can be maintained in the vehicle/equipment master data. Multi Item weighing transaction will automatically consider & populate the tare weight maintained in the master data to arrive at the “NET” weight. This eliminates the need for a second weighing of the empty vehicle to complete & post the weighing transaction thereby improving the operational efficiency. For further details, refer - Tare Weight Auto-Populate

3. Introducing Output Management and Control within Weighbridge Application

Output Management and Control in SAP S/4HANA provides a standardised framework for manging the creation, formatting and distribution of business documents such as invoices, delivery notes across different channels like print, email and electronic formats. By enabling the Weighbridge application to leverage this standard framework, we bring the same level of consistency, control and automation within waste and recycling facilities.

For further details refer - Integration with S/4 Output Management

4. Enabling Real -Time Insights with Weighing Overview Fiori App

With this release, we introduce our first analytical Fiori app providing a unified and intuitive interface to all Weighing records that allow users to monitor both internal and external weighing records. Supervisors and planners can now visualize trends, identify bottlenecks and take timely actions driving greater transparency, agility and operational excellence.

For further details refer - Weighing Overview

Want to contribute to the future roadmap?  

Join our  Continuous Influence - Waste & Recycling in S/4HANA  program today and help shape the future of Waste and Recycling in SAP S/4HANA. For more details about the program you can also refer this  blog .

entry.title: Data entity with the same name already exists
entry.content:
Scenario having multiple Data Entities named the same from different DB.  It is not possible to add an Data entity with the same name. F.e.
Project A tables:
- MainATable
- DocumentHistory
- Attachments

Project B tables:
- MainBTable
- DocumentHistory
- Attachments

This will lead you into the problem that you only can add one DocumentHistory and one Attachments table at the same time, nevertheless they don't belong together.

Instead of adding them in the background as ProjectA.DocumentHistory and ProjectB.DocumentHistory - the more I work with it, the more I get frustrated!

You can refer to 'Setup Managed Components (Services & Systems)' to see the products which CALM can be connected. 

Best regards,
SAP Support

entry.title: 🪐 Comet Browser for SAP Users: Practical Browser Automation for Fiori, SuccessFactors & Beyond
entry.content:
TL;DR

Perplexity’s new Comet browser turns everyday SAP web work (Fiori apps, SuccessFactors, BTP cockpit, Ariba, etc.) into prompt-driven automations. Think: “open My Inbox, filter purchase orders > €10k awaiting approval, export to CSV, and email me the summary.” It’s fast to try, fits neatly alongside your SAP landscape, and, used with the right guardrails, can save hours of repetitive clicks each week.


Free month of Perplexity Pro (referral)
If you want to trial Pro features while evaluating Comet for SAP workflows, use this link:
https://pplx.ai/noptus


Who is this for? 🤷‍♂️

  • Fiori power users who triage tasks in My Inbox, Manage Purchase Orders, Manage Sales Orders, or Monitor Stock daily.

  • HR operations teams working in SuccessFactors (for example, bulk checks, report exports, onboarding lists).

  • BTP administrators navigating the SAP BTP Cockpit, toggling service instances, roles, and destinations.

  • Procurement and finance teams using Ariba and S/4HANA web apps that require routine filters, exports, and cross-checks.

 

Why Comet helps SAP users 🪐

  1. Prompt to action: Ask Comet to perform structured browser tasks across tabs (navigate, search, filter, export, summarize). This acts like a “universal assistant” for your SAP web apps: especially helpful when hopping between Fiori tiles, SuccessFactors modules, and admin consoles.

  2. Research and context: Need policy reminders, note formats, or KPI definitions while inside the app? Comet augments pages with in-place explanations and follow-ups without losing context.

  3. Collections and cleanup: Group related SAP tabs (for example, period-end close) and let Comet tidy dormant tabs automatically.

  4. Familiar browsing: Built on Chromium, so everyday browsing patterns feel familiar and enterprise web apps behave as expected.

  5. Availability: Comet is broadly available with free and paid options; check Perplexity for current details.

Five high-impact automation recipes (SAP-ready) ✅

Use non-production systems first. Validate each step. Keep approvals human-in-the-loop.

  1. Fiori mass triage (My Inbox)
    “Open My Inbox > filter by ‘Overdue’ and ‘Amount > €10,000’ > group by Company Code > export summary to CSV > draft an email with top 10 items and due dates.”
    Value: reduces tab gymnastics and produces a tidy escalation brief in minutes.

  2. SuccessFactors onboarding checks
    “Open SuccessFactors > People Analytics > run ‘New Hires last 7 days’ > flag records missing manager or start date > export and summarize blockers.”
    Value: HR receives a daily exception list instead of a raw dump.

  3. Fiori spend variance pulse
    “Open Manage Purchase Orders > filter current month > variance > 5% vs contract > list top 20 by supplier; open each PO in a new tab; capture Notes; compile a one-page brief.”
    Value: pre-curated review pack for controllers.

  4. BTP cockpit housekeeping
    “Open BTP Cockpit > subaccount X > list service instances with Warning or Error state > fetch last 20 logs per instance > summarize common failures and suggest likely fixes (quota, bindings, plan).”
    Value: faster incident triage for platform teams.

  5. Ariba price drift watch
    “Ariba > reports > compare last quarter unit prices vs catalog; surface items with > 8% drift; generate CSV and bullet summary with supplier names.”
    Value: quick input for sourcing discussions.

Prompts you can copy-paste 📑

  • “Open Fiori My Inbox in S/4HANA and filter to ‘High Priority’ + ‘Overdue’. For each item, open details in a background tab, extract Vendor, Amount, Requested Delivery, and Approver Chain. Build a table and export it.”

  • “In SuccessFactors, pull Headcount by Department for the last 30 days, highlight departures, and list missing exit interviews. Draft a note to the HRBP with the topline and attach the CSV.”

  • “Go to BTP Cockpit → Subaccount X → Security → Role Collections. Snapshot role assignments changed in the last 48 hours and summarize who gained admin-like rights.”

Fit with SAP testing and governance 🧑‍⚖️

  • Do not replace UI tests: For deterministic app testing, continue using QUnit/OPA5 and your CI/CD pipeline. Comet is an operations assistant, not a test harness.

  • Least privilege: Use read-only roles whenever possible for reporting workflows; elevate only when human approvals are part of the flow.

  • SSO and audit: Run via corporate SSO, keep browser logs, and retain human approval steps for sensitive actions.

A word on security 🔐

Independent write-ups and audits have highlighted security considerations around AI-driven browsers, especially where the agent can act on web content. Best practices:

  • Disable auto-actions on untrusted sites.

  • Limit sensitive scopes (banking, payroll, personally identifiable information).

  • Pilot in sandboxes before production.
    Make an informed choice with your security team.

Getting started in 10 minutes ⏰

  1. Install Comet and sign in with your Perplexity account.

  2. Create a “SAP Ops” collection (Fiori launchpad, SuccessFactors Admin Center, BTP Cockpit, Ariba).

  3. Try one recipe above on a development tenant.

  4. Review outputs (CSV, summaries, emails) before sending.

  5. Iterate prompts: add filters, sort keys, and exception rules.

What good looks like 👍

  • Under five minutes from prompt to a usable report.

  • Human review before any approval or posting step.

  • SSO, least-privilege roles, and an audit trail retained.

  • Repeatable prompts saved to a shared team collection.

 

Final thoughts

Comet will not replace your SAP skills; it amplifies them.

Start with simple browser flows you repeat daily, keep humans in the loop, and let the assistant handle the clicks while you focus on decisions. If your team already lives in Fiori and SuccessFactors, this is one of the lowest-friction AI wins you can pilot this quarter.

For long-term fit (policies, data residency, enterprise controls), involve your security and platform teams early and evaluate Comet alongside your existing SAP governance and testing practices.

the relationship between 3F0 and UPA is same for many other scope items such as overhead accounting, asset accounting, actual costing etc. please see the blog about UPA Universal Parallel Accounting in SAP S/4HANA - SAP Community

entry.title: Re: Cross-Company Code Cost Allocation and Cost Center Tr...
entry.content:
Dear byd,

Thank you for your questions which I will try to answer below and also provide some general feedback / considerations:

Cost allocations in SAP Cloud ERP (S/4HANA Public Cloud) are by default enabled between different company codes (within one system and Controlling Area). The supported Apps are mentioned in sap help which also refers to required configurations (e.g.  Define Intercompany Clearing Accounts, Define Intercompany Margin Accounts, ...).

As all such postings are Management Accounting related (and thus e.g. posted w/o tax) the compliant reflection of such exchanged services under tax transfer pricing and local stat accounting requirements need to be considered. 
SAP offers the solution Intercompany Billing of Cross Company Cost Allocations (Scope Item 4AN).
Please check this blog which provides a very good overview: https://community.sap.com/t5/enterprise-resource-planning-blog-posts-by-sap/intercompany-cost-allocations-in-s-4hana-cloud/ba-p/13442721 

Regarding the questions

1. Cost Allocation Between Company Codes:
- Is it possible to perform cost allocation (assessment/distribution) between different company codes within the same client?
yes
- If yes, which scope item(s) should be activated?
universal allocation (2QL), for compliant reflection please check whether 4AN might be an option to legally reflect the transactions / services exchanged. 
- Which Fiori app(s) should be used?
depends on what is appropriate - refer to list of supported Apps

2. Cost Center Transfer Between Company Codes:
- Is it possible to transfer costs between cost centers in different company codes within the same client?
yes
- If yes, which scope item(s) should be activated?
see above 
- Which Fiori app(s) should be used?
see above 

Kind regards

Thorsten

entry.content:
Hi,
the only way I could think of is creating 13 test plans and assign the case to a different tester in each plan.

Not knowing your project, I feel like this is somewhat of a niche case, as I usually see each test case being executed only once per test cycle.
Wouldn't executing the same case 13 times be a massive duplication of effort?

Small remark regarding "overwritten": Test results are never "overwritten". You would instead just create a new run for the test case  with each execution. Old runs will still be visible. But as only the youngest run is relevant for reporting this does not solve your problem.

entry.title: How to determine whether the SF OIDC Migration has been successful from the UI of IAS
entry.content:
Since it is a mass run, the failed applications can be identified from the process. However, even if an application is not among the failed ones, it does not necessarily mean there is absolutely no success information. Therefore, this article provides a method for judging from the UI to facilitate the IAS Admin to directly determine whether the migration was successful.

Steps:

1. Go to Applications list:

2. Find your SF applications. The subtitle is like: https://www.successfactors.com/{CompanyId}

3. Check 3 points:

  1. protocol type is: SAML 2.0 & OpenID Connect
  2. Open Id Configuration tile can be found
  3. Client Authentication tile is disabled

 

If all 3 check points have been passed, it indicates that the migration has been successful.
